name: Avoid large Classes - too many Methods (C++)
Avoid large Classes - too many Data Members (C++)
Avoid large Interfaces - too many Methods (C++)
Avoid large Classes - too many Constructors (C++)
Avoid Classes with multiple inheritance
Avoid Classes with at least one virtual Function and without a virtual Destructor
Ensure you provide a user-defined copy constructor or disable copy when a class allocates memory in its constructor
Avoid circular references between header files
Avoid base Classes without virtual Destructors
Avoid invocation of virtual Methods of the declared Class in a Constructor or Destructor
Never throw an exception from a Destructor
Triggers should not directly modify tables, a procedure or function should be used instead
Prefer using shared error-page elements via web.xml to better control error handling
Prefer using JSP Standard Tag Library (JSTL) instead of JSP scriptlets as easier to read and to maintain
Ensure you review the Class design to reduce the number of Methods
Ensure you review the Class design to reduce the number of Constructors
Ensure that the classes have a resonable number of fields
Ensure that the interfaces have a reasonable number of methods
Ensure you declare the type as an interface of a more appropriate collection
Ensure you declare the type as an interface of a more appropriate collection.
Prefer not using 'java.io.File' to avoid violating the Enterprise JavaBeans (EJB) specification
Prefer using environment file instead of using java.lang.System.getenv()
Ensure you don't use 'java.lang.Runtime.exec()'
Ensure you don't use 'java.System.exit()' to know what happened when you exit your program
Prefer using the exception error handling model instead of 'java.lang.Error'
Ensure you no longer use 'sun.*' Classes
Prefer not using anonymous Classes for maintenance reason
Ensure you don't use JNI for security reason
A clone method that is overridden in a subclass should call super.clone. Not doing so causes the subclass clone to return an object of the wrong type.
Prefer calling "super.finalize()" at the end of "Object.finalize()" implementations
Ensure that classes are not inheriting from java.lang.Throwable.
Ensure to throw an exception which has been declared
Prefer using logging framework  as SLF4j instead of  'System.err' or 'System.out'
Ensure to have other ways of listing errors outside a try/catch  than 'System.err' and 'System.out'
Ensure to not use default stream(System.Err) for printStackTrace to print throwable and its stack trace in order to protect sensitive information.
Ensure to use class invocation or method call instead of dynamic instantiation known to be slower
Ensure that the class is implementing a reasonable number of Interfaces
Ensure that all classes that reference the database are in a specific layer usually called data layer
Ensure that action mappings have few forwards to avoid managing too complex behaviors in the Action class
Ensure that application architecture in not too complex and move some of this logic to another conceptual layer
Ensure to use the action mapping table in struts configuration file.
Ensure to have action classes that have only 1 public method
Ensure to reference only Java Objects belonging to the scope in order to respect the usage context in a JSP page.
Ensure that JSP Pages are accessed through their tiles definition
Ensure to store global information in HttpSession, or use stateful session beans that are specifically targeted for this purpose
Ensure to use local variables inside your methods, and pass whatever data you need to other methods in the class via parameters
Ensure to remove unused and unnecessary Java imports
Ensure to have Action Class inherit from one single extension of Struts Action Class that is abstract or have an abstract method.
User Interface elements must not use directly the database
Avoid Namespaces with High Efferent Coupling (CE)
Avoid namespaces with High Afferent Coupling (CA)
Never define static variables in header files
Avoid Classes with Destructor not explicitly virtual whenever one of its base Class has a virtual Destructor
Avoid functions overriding virtual functions without having the 'virtual' keyword
Avoid artifacts having recursive calls
Ensure to overrides equals() and hashCode()
Ensure to have the exact name and signature for each method and ensure having the '@Override' annotation when you need overriding a method declared in a superclass (for JSE 5.0 or later)
Prefer not using this within Constructor in multi-thread environment to avoid unpredictable behavior
Prefer not using Double checked locking for JSE 4.x and previous version
Ensure that equals() and hashCode() are defined for component as they do not have an identifier property
Ensure to use version attribute instead of timestamp for Hibernate Entity
An exception should be correctly handled according to its type and not by using an assertion
Ensure that exceptions  throwed in a catch block  are cached
Prefer using SLF4J that acts as a facade for different logging frameworks instead of using basic java log files
Ensure that session.setFlushMode(FlushMode.COMMIT, FlushMode.NEVER or FlushMode.MANUAL)  is not used
Prefer not using auto-wiring to guarantee more flexibility and better performance of your application
Ensure not using/defining singleton or factory for Spring Based application
Avoid empty finally blocks
Avoid empty catch blocks
Avoid Classes with a High Number Of Children
Always Subclass Exception and throw the subclassed Classes, do not throw the exception Exception.
Avoid Tables with more than 20 columns on an OLTP system
Ensure you catch subclass of Exception, RuntimeException or Throwable
Ensure not using jump statements inside a finally block so that any RuntimeException could be propagated and not discarded
Prefer using stored procedure instead of using direct SQL queries to database
Ensure your JSP/ASP pages are not directly connected to database
Abstract Classes should be non copy-assignable
Avoid redeclaring and overriding Methods with different default parameter values
Avoid Constructors not supplying an initial value for all non-static data members
Override all overloads of a base Class virtual Method
Ensure you have a number of local methods and remote methods called by methods in the Class below a predefined threshold
Avoid local variables that are not initialized at declaration time
Avoid 'catch-all' statement
Never perform C-style cast between incompatible Class pointers
Avoid using 'delete this'
Avoid Classes with a copy Constructor and the default Destructor or assignment operator
Avoid data members that are never read
Do not overload the ampersand, comma, logical AND or logical OR operators
Ensure you don't overwrite member of a class in its subclass.
Avoid Classes with a non-empty Destructor and the default assignment operator or copy Constructor
Avoid Classes with an assignment operator and the default Destructor or copy constructor
Ensure you don't forget the default clause in your switch statement
Ensure you don't use multiple break statement in 'for' loops
Do not hide declarations in other scopes
Avoid setting a pointer to the address of a local variable defined in a lower scope
Avoid calling blocking functions with an infinite timeout
Method override fails due to mismatch of const/volatile qualifiers
A pointer to a derived Class shall only be cast implicitly to a pointer to base Class
A pointer to a base Class shall only be cast to a pointer to a derived Class by means of 'dynamic_cast'
An unconditional 'throw', 'return' or 'break' shall terminate every non-empty switch-clause
Assignment operator should assign all non-static members of the target object
Do not alter a control variable in the body of a 'for' statement
Never define collection of 'std::auto_ptr'
Avoid using 'class' or 'struct' parameters with variadic Functions
Avoid using 'new[]', prefer 'std::vector' or 'std::array'
Casting from pointer to base Class to pointer to derived Class should be done through 'dynamic_cast' or 'static_cast'
Avoid using NaN to test the result of an expression
Avoid locking of Objects with weak identities
Ensure that testing floating point numbers for equality is not used as is source of imprecision
Ensure not having hard-coded network resources names in the source files (JEE)
Ensure data handling operations are properly encapsulated to provide clear status of the execution
Ensure to have CDI Beans with normal scope proxyable
Avoid artifacts having Incorrect Type Conversion or Cast
Avoid using Parse for primitive types and used instead TryParse
Ensure not using incorrect numeric type conversions to avoid data corruption
Always check the content type when receiving a HTTP post
Prefer not using deprecated methods, constructors, fields, type or packages
Ensure you keep simple the design of the component/module to reduce number of independent paths
Make sure that you do not use Web SQL databases
Avoid using delete with no object properties
To delete or remove an index element from an array use splice, pop or shift rather than delete to prevent empty indexes
Ensure that there are no references to subclass in the superclass to subdue complexity of your code
Ensure to not use Javascript Function constructor calling a string represented source code to prevent impaired performance
Ensure that you are not using a break or return statement inside a finally block, to avoid dead code
Make sure to not access the database from Javascript directly, instead create dedicated modules for the same
Aggregate method parameters into an object to improve readability and maintainability of your code
Always use JSON.parse & JSON.stringify with try/catch block because of the synchronous call(Javascript)
Ensure get() function always return a value
Ensure you don't use <textarea> with child elements such as inner text, if it has the v-model attribute
Ensure that you define a key for v-for
Avoid using v-show directive inside templates
Ensure that you use $emit to emit events instead of $parent to directly change parent props, to maintain the vue philosophy of props down events up
Ensure not using anonymous functions to attach events because they are difficult to debug, maintain, test or reuse
Ensure you don't use officially jQuery deprecated methods
Ensure you have implemented expected $ajax callbacks
Ensure you have properly manage errors by using the error/fail callbacks
Ensure you have overwritten component methods to properly catch errors
Ensure you have properly use the componentDidCatch to better manage errors
Prefer using angular.fromJson and angular.toJson instead of standard JS APIs to improve maintainability and robustness of your code
Prefer using 'this' instead of $scope in controllers to generate views to ensure consistency and structuredness in code

Prefer using AngularJS wrapper service $timeout to maintain structuredness of code

Ensure that you do not use a jQuery wrapper on angular.element to ensure structuredness in code

Always throw all created error.

Invoking super should be done only once in constructor

Always ensure Superclass not knowing Subclass

You should set the process.exitCode to allow the process exiting naturally rather than calling process.exit() directly.

Do not use the Thread.resume or Thread.suspend APIs.

Check if the variable is null before dereferencing it.

Always check the object is not null before using it or it is not used in a try block.
Ensure not using blocking async methods (.NET)
Always override 'Equals' and Comparison operators with IComparable implementation
Ensure the getter is not stopped by throwing exception.
Avoid returning null from ToString()
Avoid if statements and blocks that are always TRUE or FALSE
Always mark Windows Forms starting point as STAThread
Always use ConfigureAwait(false) in library code awaited tasks
Avoid having the same implementation in a conditional structure
Avoid non-public custom exception types
Avoid improper instantiation of argument exceptions
Always pass optional parameters too, when making 'base' calls
Ensure that you are not using predictable SecureRandom Seeds
Prefer using @Override annotation to mark methods overriding or implementing a method declared in a super type to avoid unintentional errors
Ensure to declare the object as serializable if you are using it as a httpsession attribute
Prefer using java.net.URI instead of java.net.URL
Prefer not using Generic Authentication Exception Class to promote easy error handling
Ensure not using ControllerAdvice And HandlerExceptionResolver simultaneously to avoid unexpected behavior
Avoid using "continue" statement
"enum" members other than the first one should not be explicitly initialized unless all members are explicitly initialized.
Avoid iterator invalidation.
Ensure that you are not using <cstdio> library
Avoid using 'setjmp' or 'longjmp' (C/C++)
Avoid using the library functions bsearch and qsort from <stdlib.h> (C/C++)

Avoid using offsetof from <cstddef>

Avoid using <stdio.h> (C/C++)
Make sure you do not use <time.h> to avoid unexpected and implementation dependent outcome
Ensure that a class type exception is always be caught by reference to avoid slicing
Ensure that Switch statements have at least 2 case clauses
All if … else if constructs shall be terminated with an else clause (C/C++)
Ensure to declare arrays with a defined size
Avoid using 'signal.h' (C/C++)
Ensure to return a proper expression for a non-void function
Avoid using the unbounded functions of <cstring> library
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block, any ellipsis (catch-all) handler shall occur last.
Ensure to separate a side effect of an expression from the sizeof method
Prefer using Integers rather than Octal Constants
Do not override the standard library functions (C/C++)
Ensure to handle exceptions inside main()
Ensure that there is at least one exception handler to catch-all otherwise unhandled exceptions in the main function(C++)
Ensure to use an integral value to iterate in loops
Ensure that testing floating point numbers for equality is not used as is source of imprecision
Ensure to split the expressions and assignments into multiple lines for better readability and maintainability.
Avoid having  a method call or additional expressions in a statement using "++" or "--" operators (C/C++)
Avoid using Digraphs (C++)
Avoid using Trigraphs
Avoid using Unions
All constructors that are callable with a single argument of fundamental type shall be declared explicit.
A base class shall be declared virtual only if it is used in a diamond hierarchy
Ensure to use C++ style notation casts to avoid unexpected type conversions
Handlers of a function-try-block implementation of a class constructor ordestructor shall not reference non-static members from this class or its bases.
Ensure that you do not convert a function pointer to any other type to avoid unexpected behavior
Ensure that pointer types are not cast to integral types
Ensure that you use 'enum' types with  [ ], =, == and !=, the unary & operator, and <, <=, >, >=.
Ensure to have boolean operands with boolean operators
Avoid having expressions with bool type to be used as operands on operators other than =, &&, ||, !, ==, !=, the unary & operator, and the conditional operator
Avoid dynamic_cast to convert current object to its derived class from its constructor or destructor
Avoid delete operators to exit with an exception.
Avoid move constructor and move assignment operator to exit with an exception
Converting a multiplication to a larger type should be done before the multiplication takes place
Avoid comparing types of different widths in a loop
Bit-fields shall be either unsigned integral, or enumeration (with underlying type of unsigned integral type).
Ensure arrays and containers are accessed using unsigned values
Avoid lines starting with "#" with invalid pre-processing directive
Undefined macro identifiers shall not be used in #if or #elif preprocessor directives, except as operands to the defined operator
Arguments to a function-like macro shall not contain tokens that look like preprocessing directives.
Avoid using # OR ## operators more than once while defining macros
Prefer defining macros in Global Namespace
Avoid using goto to jump backwards into a statement in the same function(C/C++)
Mke sure you do not have unused labels in your code
Avoid defining, redefining or undefining standard macros from standard library
Avoid using typeid in polymorphic class from the body of its constructor or destructor.
While using ORDER BY in queries prefer using Column names instead of indexes for better maintainability and readability of queries in code
Ensure that you have a limited number of paramenters in OR clauses or IN statements to ensure good query performance
Make sure the identifiers defined in SQL are not quoted <""> as it is confusing to read and reduces maintainability of code
When inserting data into columns always define column names to prevent mistakes and wrong updates
Ensure using ANSI standard Operators such as <>,<=,>= in SQL where clauses to ensure portability
Ensure to handle exception in a catch block and not leave it empty
Ensure to use WHEN OTHERS with WHEN for exception handling to prevent unexpected behavior
Ensure to propagate errors to client instead of using with NULL when handling exceptions through WHEN OTHERS
Ensure that your tables do not have large number of columns as it tends to add redundancy in data, try dividing the tables instead and link them through keys
Ensure that you do not have triggers acting on other triggers and cascading, review your design to avoid such cases
Improve the readability and maintainability of your queries by using aliases for tables
Ensure column references in queries are qualified to avoid any ambiguous and undefined references
When creating synonyms ensure that you do not reference a missing object as it will create errors at execution
Errors should be handled in stored procedures and functions
Stored Procedures should always RETURN a status value. RETURN 0 to indicate success and any non-zero value indicates failure.
Avoid Artifacts with a Complex SELECT Clause (SQL)
Avoid Functions and Procedures doing an Insert, Update or Delete without managing a transaction (SQL)
Avoid artifacts having db.collection.ensureIndex() to create new indexes
When using compound indexes, avoid having different index ordering in collection access
